review_title: Empowering Work Environment and Unmatched Benefits for Deaf and Hard of Hearing Services Campus
pros: I love working with Deaf and Hard of Hearing individuals in this environment. They have empowered me to grow and gain valuable experiences. Additionally, I have great colleagues on campus. The flexibility provided by the campus is important to me. Furthermore, the benefits offered are unmatched and cannot be compared to others. For instance, employees receive a pension, health insurance, and tuition for further education.
cons: I do not have cons.

job_title: Senior Data Developer in Washington, DC
pros: ASL Signing community and reasonable compensation for higher ed. Depending on your seniority you may have okay work-life balance.
cons: The reviews from other BIPOC here proved to be accurate - prepare to be harmed by the institution and your colleagues, supervisors, and leadership. The open letter by  National Black Deaf Advocates (NBDA), external to Gallaudet, titled "NBDA Condemns Discrimination Against BIPOC at Gallaudet University" states that "the leadership at Gallaudet has a proven record of being intentional in its effort to maintain the status quo and continue racist practices. Black and non-tenured POC Gallaudet staff are not safe!" I frequently witnessed and experienced overt and covert racism . I left because of targeted discrimination, micromanagement, transphobia, and gross mismanagement. Multiple colleagues reported these experiences too. The structures in place failed to prevent, mitigate, or remove the harm after 10 months trying to improve the working conditions. This was the worst work environment in my decade long career. Not an exaggeration. I would not recommend anyone I care about work here, unless they have no other choice. Even then, I would warn you to be prepared to be jerked around, silenced, have your needs minimized, manipulated, all while holding on to your dignity until you can get out. The institution will defend itself and prioritize its white Deaf identity no matter what.

pros: It is designed for the Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing and the language is American Sign Language-based university.
cons: It is run by the U.S. Congress. A lot of duties for a small university. NOTE: Present President Roberta Cordano, not President T. Alan Hurtwitz. This is outdated. You need to update Gallaudet's info.

review_title: Great to work with the student-athletes, but does not pay well
job_title: Assistant Track and Field Coach in Washington, DC
pros: Overall, the experience was positive. I was able to learn American Sign Language (ASL) and share my love of the sport of track and field with the student-athletes. The job offered reasonable flexibility as the student-athletes had practice times arranged with the coaching staff at times as a whole team, and often times later in the year individually with their event coach. Second, additional work such as practice and competition planning can be done remotely at your home office, with a need to only be on campus for practices and competitions.
cons: There are a few cons for this position: 1) Payment for this position is very low and makes it hard to make enough money to live off of 2) follow up with payment and benefits, employment status is a part-time temporary employee as such hiring and termination happened during each season (Cross Country and Track & Field) which meant I was not able to get benefits such as health insurance or tuition remission, etc due to not being continuously employed due to the hiring and termination practice 3) There was challenges dealing with the Athletic Department administration not fully supporting the students - athletes and teams due to a culture of low expectations and low performance standards due to the sports being NCAA Division III and a majority of the student-athletes being deaf. So that was a challenge to work through with both the athletic department and student-athletes 4) There were some challenges working collaboratively with the other coaches primarily the strength and conditioning coaches stemming from the culture of low performance and low expectations, the lead to the strength coaches not believing the athletic abilities of the student - athletes. Second, the strength and conditioning coaches were resistant to plan the strength training programs for the student - athletes and rarely communicated progress in strength training. This leads to challenges in helping the student-athletes have a full complementary track and field training and strength training programs to reach their full athletic potential.

pros: Full-time, live/breathe ASL, federal benefits
cons: Can be very tough with not many years in the field.

pros: Interaction with students, good benefits, tuition assistance, and absolutely beautiful campus/grounds
cons:
Deeply embedded racist practices against African Americans specifically. The University does not have an issue with people of color in general, but  hinders and targets black employees specifically.


#2
Not enough focus on education, and whether graduates are prepared for the real world. Too much focus on projecting an imagine of itself  to the world that isn't real.

review_title: Grand pride in the University as a student (more than 6 years)
pros: My positions were as a student assistant, and a building supervisor for the Office of Alumni Relations. They were great at letting me be flexible with my hours, and giving me the chance to focus on my education. My Executive Director, and Assist Executive Director  that I worked with all were very supportive of any projects, and building supervisor that I worked on.
cons: The only downside was that I graduated, and i could not work in my positions anymore. My building supervisor position was reduced to a part time contract employee working hours.
